'''Dorothea Lambert Chambers''' (née '''Dorothea Katherine Douglass''', 3 September 1878 – 7 January 1960)<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W39oSS7c2xAC&pg=PA87 |title=Historical Dictionary of Tennis |last=Grasso |first=John |date=2011-09-16 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-7237-0 |pages=87 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> was a British [[tennis]] player. She won seven [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] Women's Singles titles and a gold medal at the [[Tennis at the 1908 Summer Olympics|1908 Summer Olympics]].

==Tennis==
In 1900 Douglass made her singles debut at [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] and, after a bye in the first round, lost her second round match to [[Louisa Martin]]. Three years later, she won her first of seven ladies [[Singles (tennis)|singles]] titles. On 6 April 1907 she married Robert Lambert Chambers and was thereafter known by her married surname Lambert Chambers.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Hartley|editor1-first=Cathy|title=A Historical Dictionary of British Women|date=2003|publisher=Europa Publications|location=London [u.a.]|isbn=978-1857432282|page=194|edition=Rev.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Men and Matters|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000164/19070408/159/0008|work=Dundee Courier|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|date=8 April 1907|page=8|url-access=subscription }}</ref>

In 1908 she won the gold medal in the [[Tennis at the 1908 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] event at the [[1908 Summer Olympics]] after a straight-sets victory in the final against compatriot [[Dora Boothby]].<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/la/dorothy-lambert-chambers-1.html |title=Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers Olympic Results |accessdate=2014-01-30 |work=sports-reference.com |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202160059/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/la/dorothy-lambert-chambers-1.html |archivedate=2 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

She wrote ''Tennis for Ladies'', which was published in 1910. The book contained photographs of tennis techniques and contained advice on attire and equipment.

In 1911 Lambert Chambers won the women's final at Wimbledon against Dora Boothby 6–0, 6–0, the first player to win a [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] singles final without losing a game.<ref>{{Tennis Hall of Fame}}</ref> The only other female player to achieve this was [[Steffi Graf]] when she defeated [[Natalia Zvereva]] in the [[1988 French Open]] final.<ref>{{cite news|author=ROBIN HERMAN |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/05/sports/tennis-graf-shuts-out-zvereva-to-gain-french-open-title.html |title=TENNIS – Graf Shuts Out Zvereva to Gain French Open Title |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=1988-06-05 |accessdate=2017-06-23 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>

In 1919 Lambert Chambers played the longest Wimbledon final up to that time: 44 games against Frenchwoman [[Suzanne Lenglen]]. Lambert Chambers held two match points at 6–5 in the third set but eventually lost to Lenglen 8–10, 6–4, 7–9.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15252766 |title=Ladies' Lawn Tennis. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=10 June 1911 |page=7 |via=[[National Library of Australia]]}}</ref>

Lambert Chambers only played sporadic singles after 1921 but continued to compete in doubles until 1927. She made the singles quarter-finals of the US Open in 1925<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/104979/Dorothea-Lambert-Chambers | title=Encyclopædia Britannica Biography | accessdate=2013-05-06}}</ref> and, from 1924 to 1926, she captained Britain's [[Wightman Cup]] team. In the [[1925 Wightman Cup]] edition she played, at the age of 46, a singles (against [[Eleanor Goss]]) and doubles match and won both.<ref>{{cite news|title=British Women in Tennis Victories|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=c7stAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0osFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6885%2C1939350|newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]]|date=18 August 1925|via=[[Google News Archive]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Woman at Tennis|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zo8TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lpYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7153%2C476536|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=17 August 1925|via=[[Google News Archive]]}}</ref>  In 1928 she turned to professional coaching.

Lambert Chambers was inducted into the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]] in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hall of Famers – Dorothea Douglass Chambers|url=https://www.tennisfame.com/hall-of-famers/dorothea-douglass-chambers|website=www.tennisfame.com|publisher=[[International Tennis Hall of Fame]]|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402122559/https://www.tennisfame.com/hall-of-famers/dorothea-douglass-chambers|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She died in [[Kensington]], London.

==Badminton==
In addition to playing tennis Lambert Chambers was one of the leading badminton players at the beginning of the 20th century. In 1903, 1904 and 1907 she was the runner-up at the singles event of the [[All England Badminton Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mrs Lambert Chambers|url=http://www.badmintonengland.co.uk/text.asp?section=1778#.VQDj_9LF8rs|publisher=Badminton England|access-date=12 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304194032/http://www.badmintonengland.co.uk/text.asp?section=1778#.VQDj_9LF8rs|archive-date=4 March 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>

==Personal life==
During the [[First World War]] she undertook war work, first at [[Ealing Hospital]], and later at the Little Theatre.<ref>The Sportswoman's Page, ''The Illustrated Sporting and Dramatic News'', December 22, 1917, p508</ref>
